Crnogorski ministar podneo ostavku zbog snimka korupcije

01 Nov 2019, 13:20

Ministar održivog razvoja i turizma Crne Gore Pavle Radulović podneo je ostavku na tu funkciju nakon što je objavljen snimak dva inspektora koja uzimaju mito od jednog lokalnog biznismena."Niko mi nije sugerisao da podnesem ostavku, ovo je moj lični odnos prema poslu, biznis etika mora da postoji i u državnoj upravi", rekao je Radulović i dodao da je ostavku podneo pisanim putem.On je dodao da "ne zna ima li gradjanina koji pošteno plaća porez a da mu sinoć nije bilo teško".Kako je naveo, snimak od sinoć je potvrda tvrdnji koje su imali rekla-kazala."Oba inspektora i dalje rade u Ministarstvu. Ministarstvo je preuzelo u decembru 2017. poslove inspekcijske uprave i zateklo ta dva inspektora", dodao je Radulović.Radulović je objasnio i da su pre snimka pokrenuli postupak, ali da je odgovornost nesumnjiva jer ti ljudi i dalje rade kao inspektori. "Poslali smo ih na neko gradilište i oni su reagovali tek nakon osam dana...", dodao je Radulović."Nisam uspeo da iskorenim ovakvo ponašanje, nije bitno kada se desilo. Jutros sam pokrenuo novi postupak protiv ove dvojice, nakon materijalnih dokaza, i nadam se da će biti uspešniji od ostalih", rekao je on.On je pozvao tužilaštvo da do detalja ispita svaki navod i dodao da im Ministarstvo stoji na raspolaganju.U emisiji "Načisto", na crnogorskoj TV Vijesti, u četvrtak je emitovan snimak razgovora investitora u Budvi s gradjevinskim inspektorima Zoranom Boškovićem i Vladanom Juretićem.Investitor govori da je doneo 5.000 od 20.000 evra, koliko mu je navodno traženo, a Bošković ga savetuje kako da ne otkriju da unajmljuje radnike na crno.Drugi inspektor, Juretić, poznat je javnosti od decembra 2009. kada se tadašnji predsednik Crne Gore Filip Vujanović založio za njega i pomilovanjem izdejstvovao da Juretić izbegne dve zatvorske kazne za nanošenje teških telesnih povreda i za zloupotrebu položaja.U četvrtak uveče generalna direktorka Direktorata za inspekcijski nadzor i licenciranje Rina Ivančević kazala je da je "šokirana snimkom" razgovora inspektora i investitora koji je videla.

Montenegrin minister resigns over a recording of corruption

01 Nov 2019, 12:20

Minister of Sustainable Development and Tourism of Montenegro Pavle Radulovic resigned after posting a video of two inspectors taking bribes from a local businessman. "Nobody suggested that I resign, this is my personal attitude to work, business ethics must that he also exists in the state administration, "Radulovic said, adding that he had resigned in writing. He added that he" did not know if there was a citizen who was paying his taxes fairly and that it was not difficult for him last night. " "Both inspectors are still working in the Ministry. In December 2017, the Ministry took over the duties of the inspection administration and found these two inspectors," Radulovic added.Radulovic explained that they had started the procedure before the recording. but that the responsibility is beyond doubt as these people continue to work as inspectors. "We sent them to a construction site and they reacted only after eight days ..." Radulovic added. "I failed to eradicate this behavior, it doesn't matter when it happened. This morning, I started a new case against these two, after material evidence. , and I hope they will be more successful than the others, "he said. He called on the prosecution to examine each allegation in detail, adding that the ministry was at their disposal. On" Clearly ", on Montenegrin TV News, it was broadcast on Thursday recording of investor talks in Budva with construction inspectors Zoran Boskovic and Vladan Juretic. The investor says he brought in 5,000 of the 20,000 euros he was allegedly asked for, and Boskovic advises him not to reveal that he hires black workers. Another inspector, Juretic, known since December 2009, when Montenegrin President Filip Vujanovic pleaded for him with a pardon and demanded that Juretic avoid two prison sentences for causing heavy bodily harm. h injury and abuse of office.On Thursday night, Director General of the Directorate for Inspection and Licensing Rina Ivancevic said she was "shocked by the recording" of a conversation between inspectors and investors she saw.
